Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Research and development of chip-integrated, magnetic-resonance-based platforms for chemical sensing of trace systems and nuclear polarization of fluids
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this GOALI (Grant Opportunities for Academic Liaison with Industry) award from the Chemical Measurements and Imaging program in the Chemistry Division and the Office of Multidisciplinary Activities in the Mathematics and Physical Sciences Directorate, Professors Carlos Meriles at the City College of New York (CCNY) and Orlando Auciello of the University of Texas at Dallas and their students will partner with investigators at Advanced Diamond Technologies, Inc. (ADT), Romeoville, IL to perform basic and applied research and development of novel technologies that exploit the properties of near-surface paramagnetic defects in diamond. The project will combine crystal growth techniques, spin control schemes, and microfluidics and molecular labeling technology to develop chip-integrated structures where a target analyte is brought in contact with paramagnetic centers -- specifically nitrogen-vacancy (NV) centers and substitutional nitrogen -- generated near the surface of ultra-pure diamond. The central goal is to use the paramagnetic centers as sensitive probes tailored to detect the presence of pre-defined trace materials in solution. The research plan includes a range of proof-of-principle experiments explicitly conceived to facilitate the transfer of these sensing technologies to the market. The basic and applied science to be performed and the systems that will ensue are likely to find broad use ranging from chemical analysis and medical diagnostics, to bio-defense, environmental monitoring, and food safety.

Magnetic resonance (MR) measurements are well known for the usefulness in medical imaging, but a close variant of these measurements are widely used in chemical analysis because they provide a wealth of information about sample composition and molecular structure. However, the detection limits of MR measurements are typically too high for use in trace analyses, such as environmental monitoring and medical diagnostics. This project will seek to lower the detection limits of MR measurements by coupling the target molecule to tags that produce very strong MR signals as they interact with deliberately induced defects in diamond films. Besides the technological and scientific advantages, this project will enrich the education of PhD students and postdocs through training in entrepreneurship and new venture creation. To meet this goal, the investigators plan various activities that build on the close ties to their industrial collaborator ADT, a company presently commercializing a new generation of industrial and biodevices based on exclusive thin-film diamond technology. The proposed R&D program includes internships for students and postdocs under the combined supervision of an academic mentor and an industry partner, student-oriented seminars by lead industrial scientists, and regular cyber-enabled interactions designed to facilitate the transfer of research results to industry. These plans gain special meaning at CCNY and UTD, two institutions with a large population of minority students. Capitalizing on the various recruitment channels at hand, the teaching, mentoring and career counseling components of this project will truly broaden participation, while encouraging groups underrepresented in the sciences to pursue scientific careers both in academia and industry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Diamond provides a unique platform material with extreme properties and multifunctionalities enabling an ever growing range of applications. For example, as the hardest material known, diamond is the obliged choice for the fabrication of long-lasting machining and cutting tools; being a wide-bandgap semiconductor, diamond also finds application in power electronics due to its outstanding thermal conductivity, and as a window material transparent to electromagnetic radiation over a broad wavelength range. 

Every diamond contains atoms other than carbon whose varying concentration and composition give gems their signature colors (e.g., nitrogen is the dominant impurity in yellowish crystals while blue color comes from boron dopants). Impurities are generally avoided, but sometimes they are introduced intentionally as a way to control certain properties. An example central to this project is the negatively-charged nitrogen-vacancy (NV) center, a defect whose intrinsic magnetic moment (or 'spin') can be polarized to nearly 100% under ambient conditions only with the aid of optical illumination. This is a remarkable property, specially if we use as a reference the polarization attainable within the strongest available magnets, several orders of magnitude inferior. 

This project focused on the use of NV centers as a source to polarize other spins that are not amenable to optical hyperpolarization; in particular we focused on nuclear spins within the diamond crystal or in other materials - especially fluids - brought in contact with its surface. The long-term goal of this work is to produce hyperpolarized fluids on-demand that can be subsequently used for various applications in the pharmaceutical, food, and health­care industries (to mention just some examples). Assuming sufficiently large amounts of liquids can be hyperpolarized, these techniques are also likely to find use for medical MRI, point-­of-­care diagnostics, and portable magnetic resonance. 

Throughout the duration of this grant we developed extensive infrastructure in the form of customized low- and high-field magnetic resonance systems, and on-chip microfluidic devices tailored to polarize liquids brought in contact with integrated diamond structures. We introduced and explored a variety of polarization protocols to optimize the polarization transfer from NVs to nuclear spins and investigated alternate routes to creating shallow NVs over extended, micro-crystalline surfaces. We attained record levels of 13C spin polarization within diamond, though we could not unambigously demonstrate transfer to outside target fluids. The knowledge we have gained, nonetheless, lay the ground for future research activities.

Two important highlights of our work are the detailed understanding we gained on the dynamics of 13C spin pumping in diamond, and the demonstration of 13C hyperpolarization in diamond powders. In particular, the latter result - previously prevented due to problems arising from the random orientation of the diamond crystals - is likely to have a broad impact in the field, as it enormously enhances the diamond surface-­to-­volume ratio, thus facilitating the transfer to material systems proximal to the surface. The improved understanding we have gained on the dynamics of spin polarization transfer is also paving the way towards the development of miniature, on-­chip polarization prototypes. One such device, designed to polarize and transport hyperpolarized diamond micro- and nano-crystals as contrast agents for enhanced­-sensitivity 13C MRI, is presently under development. This progress, in turn, should prove critical in consolidating the interaction with industrial partners interested in moving this technology forward.

The successful implementation of room temperature nuclear spin hyperpolarization techniques is intimately related to the realization of miniature, high-­detection-­sensitivity NMR devices. Such systems are destined to have a tremendous impact through the low­-cost application of NMR to areas where magnetic resonance -­ though useful -­ has been deemed too costly. Examples include the deployment of NMR systems for battlefield diagnostics, health care in difficult-­to­-reach areas, material characterization during outer space exploration, high­-throughput analysis of pharmaceutical drugs, industrial quality control, etc.
